title: 105_hr1072
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on Military Justice and Fairness Act" and establishes a commission. The "Commission on Military Justice and Fairness" is established with 15 members appointed by the President and the majority leader of the House of Representatives. The "Commission on Military Justice and Fairness" consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders, with specific limitations on the number of members from the Armed Forces. Each member must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission on Military Justice and Fairness consists of 15 members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Chairman is designated by the President, members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as original appointments, and expedited security clearances are provided by the Secretary of Defense. The Commission on Military Justice and Fairness consists of 15 members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with the Chairman designated by the President. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as original appointments, and expedited security clearances are provided by the Secretary of Defense. SEC. 3. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission will investigate safeguards for Armed Forces members reporting sexual misconduct, harassment, and discrimination, assess investigative mechanisms, and evaluate the training and independence of investigating officers and trial counsel. The Commission will investigate the independence necessary for fair investigations of sexual misconduct allegations in the Armed Forces, including the referral of cases for administrative hearings instead of court-martial proceedings, mechanisms for resolving complaints, and the potential remedy of damages and attorneys fees for victims. The Commission will also examine gender discrimination, court-martial jurisdiction over non-service related offenses, procedures for apprehending and charging accused members of the Armed Forces, selection of jurors in military justice system, and the need for independent judge advocate defense counsel. The Commission will also address issues such as the independence of military judges, uniformity in sentencing, judicial review of military personnel decisions, and the effectiveness of correctional programs for offenders in the Armed Forces. The Commission will address issues related to the Armed Forces, including procedural protections for career military personnel, statistical data collection on crime and misconduct, and the exchange of criminal records among military courts. The criminal records of Armed Forces members should be regularly reported to the National Crime Information Center. Consider establishing rulemaking committees with civilian members for the military justice system. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within one year of all members being appointed, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative action. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, obtain necessary information from government agencies, and issue subpoenas to compel witness testimony and evidence related to investigations. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas and orders for compliance. It can also contract with government and private agencies for goods and services without following certain statutes. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PROCEDURES. The Commission shall meet as called by the Chairman or majority of members. Eight members constitute a quorum for meetings. Any member or agent can take authorized actions on behalf of the Commission. SEC. 7. PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Commission may appoint a staff director and additional personnel without following certain appointment rules. They can set pay rates for staff members without adhering to standard classification and pay rate regulations. The Commission can appoint staff without following standard rules and set pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule for some personnel and GS-15 for others. SEC. 8. OTHER ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Commission may use postal and printing services, obtain administrative support services from the Secretary of Defense, procure experts and consultants, request personnel from federal agencies, and accept gifts, bequests, and devises. The Commission may accept gifts, bequests, or devises of services or property, including money and proceeds from sales, for its work. These gifts shall be deposited in the Treasury and disbursed upon the Commission's order. SEC. 9. PAYMENT OF COMMISSION EXPENSES. The Commission's travel expenses, per diem allowances, and employee compensation will be paid from Department of Defense funds. Other expenses will also be covered by Department of Defense funds. The Secretary of Defense will promptly transfer funds to the Commission upon request by the Chairman. SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. The Commission will terminate within 90 days of submitting its report to the President and Congress.
